zeroshade commented on a change in pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#discussion_r738807666



##########
File path: go/parquet/writer_properties.go
##########
@@ -18,7 +18,7 @@ package parquet
 
 import (
 	"github.com/apache/arrow/go/arrow/memory"

Review comment:
       I can't upgrade the dependency to v6 in this branch until there exists a `go/arrow/v6.X.Y` tag which has the go.mod containing the `/v6` in the module name. The `go.sum` file in here is a checksum of the dependencies, and I can't get it to upgrade to the v6 until the tag exists with a correct go.mod.
   
   The only way to have the `/v6` suffix here would be for us to merge the arrow and parquet packages into a single module with the two separate packages instead of maintaining them as two entirely separate modules. Which i'm increasingly thinking we should do.




-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

zeroshade commented on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954268795


   @kou i've updated this PR to switch the arrow and parquet packages from being two separate modules to a single module with two packages. This means that they can more easily be kept in sync for the versioning and means we only need 1 tag when versioning. I've also included the change to the `post-13-go.sh` file to use the updated tag and remove the unneeded one.


--

kou commented on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954319935


   I'm sorry but I'm not familiar with Go. (@emkornfield are you familiar with Go?)
   I'm not sure whether this change is backward incompatible change or not.
   
   Could you tell me how to install/use Apache Arrow Go before 6.0.0 such as Apache Arrow Go 5.0.0?
   Can we use the method for 6.0.0? Or is the method broken by 6.0.0?
   


--

zeroshade commented on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954334003


   @kou the philosophy for go is that major version upgrades are only ever done for breaking changes, if it's not a breaking change then it shouldn't be a major version upgrade. The only reason I'm advocating it is to keep the version number in line with the other implementations. 
   
   As such this change is intentionally backwards incompatible, a user would have to explicitly upgrade their import statements if they upgrade to this version.


--

zeroshade edited a comment on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954334003


   @kou the philosophy for go is that major version upgrades are only ever done for breaking changes, if it's not a breaking change then it shouldn't be a major version upgrade. The only reason I'm advocating it is to keep the version number in line with the other implementations. 
   
   As such this change is intentionally backwards incompatible, a user would have to explicitly upgrade their import statements if they upgrade to this version. Specifically it would only make them upgrade their import statements, but that would be the case for any major version upgrade, and doesn't have much to do with the shift of the way the modules are defined.


--

zeroshade edited a comment on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954334003


   @kou the philosophy for go is that major version upgrades are only ever done for breaking changes, if it's not a breaking change then it shouldn't be a major version upgrade. The only reason I'm advocating it is to keep the version number in line with the other implementations. 
   
   As such this change is intentionally backwards incompatible, a user would have to explicitly upgrade their import statements if they upgrade to this version. Specifically it would only make them upgrade their import statements, but that would be the case for any major version upgrade, and doesn't have much to do with the shift of the way the modules are defined.
   
   To install Arrow via go in current versions, you just run `go get github.com/apache/arrow/go/arrow`. Before this change, you cannot specify the version by number, you have to use commit identifiers and so on because we didn't tag them.
   
   This change doesn't break that method at all, but it will allow specifying versions by number going forward. It just might be necessary to manually change the import statements to the new v6 path to do the upgrade rather then the tooling being able to do it for you.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

zeroshade edited a comment on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954334003


   @kou the philosophy for go is that major version upgrades are only ever done for breaking changes, if it's not a breaking change then it shouldn't be a major version upgrade. The only reason I'm advocating it is to keep the version number in line with the other implementations. 
   
   As such this change is intentionally backwards incompatible, a user would have to explicitly upgrade their import statements if they upgrade to this version. Specifically it would only make them upgrade their import statements, but that would be the case for any major version upgrade, and doesn't have much to do with the shift of the way the modules are defined.
   
   To install Arrow via go in current versions, you just run `go get github.com/apache/arrow/go/arrow`. Before this change, you cannot specify the version by number, you have to use commit identifiers and so on because we didn't tag them.
   
   This change doesn't break that method at all, but it will allow specifying versions by number going forward. It just might be necessary to manually change the import statements to the new v6 path to do the upgrade rather then the tooling being able to do it for you.
   
   **Edit** actually, to install the new version they'd do `go get github.com/apache/arrow/go/v6/arrow` note the addition of the v6 to the path


--

emkornfield commented on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954474900


   So we will need to make this broad change on every release?  I'm not an expert enough in go to know if this is wise.  At the very least for such a large change, we should probably advertise in the dev@ mailing list.


--

zeroshade commented on pull request #11570:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11570#issuecomment-954775055


   @emkornfield If we want to keep the major version number the same for the Go lib as it is for the rest of them, then yes we'd need to make this broad change on every major release. It's part of the reason why standard Go library development is to avoid major version upgrades unless you actually make a breaking change. By changing the import path you can actually have a new version and old major version side by side in a project if necessary etc. it's actually easier on consumers surprisingly. I can make a post in the dev@ mailing list about this


--
